awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT: An Artificial Intelligence Capability to Accelerate Low-Cost Commercial Polymer Design
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project includes the creation of an accelerated low-cost capability for polymer selection, design and discovery for many industries. The proposed project will advance the development of machine learning for the traditional, laborious and expensive trial-and-error approaches to materials development. The total R&D expenditure of the polymer manufacturing industry is about $10 billion per year, with anticipated savings of one estimated $100 million per year in the United States.  In addition, the acceleration of product design workflows could dramatically shorten time-to-market for new products.  Finally, the proposed project includes entrepreneurial mentoring.

The proposed project will help create a data-driven machine learning based capability and service to achieve accelerated application-specific polymer design and development. Machine learning (ML) algorithms “trained” on an underlying database produce predictive models, which can (1) make instantaneous predictions of properties of a new yet-to-be-synthesized polymer, and (2) make recommendations of new and existing polymers that will meet design objectives. The proposed project will advance the development of a prototype Polymer Genome online tool.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Over the years, the Ramprasad Group at Georgia Tech has developed intellectual property (IP) and innovations in Polymer Informatics, which significantly accelerate the development, design, and optimization of polymers and formulations for various applications. The NSF PFI-TT grant has played a crucial role in advancing their polymer informatics software technology and facilitating its transition to the commercial space. The following are some key outcomes:

Technical Developments:

  • Collection and curation of data for dozens of polymer and composite properties.
  • Training machine learning models on this data to build property prediction models.
  • Creation of innovative algorithms for numerical polymer representation.
  • Development of new learning algorithms.
  • Creation of chemical and feature variant schemes for efficient chemical and parameter space searches.

Patent Filings:

  • Three patents have been filed, with one recently issued.

Market Validation:

  • A previous NSF I-Corps grant, along with ongoing customer discovery under the NSF PFI-TT grant, enabled the team to assess the market value of their technology. This included identifying target customer segments, validating and quantifying the value proposition, and determining product-market fit for their data-driven machine learning-based polymer property prediction and polymer design software.

Spinoff Formation:

  • A spinoff company, Matmerize, Inc., has been established. The developed polymer informatics technology and IP (including patents, software, and trade secrets) have been exclusively licensed to Matmerize by Georgia Tech.
  • Matmerize has developed a cloud-based materials design software called PolymRize™, which can be accessed securely by polymer and formulations chemists via a web browser. This software uses proprietary data to build models that predict properties and aid in the rapid design of new polymers and formulations, aiming to set a new industry standard for cost-effective, accelerated polymer materials and formulation development.

Educational Impact:

  • The NSF PFI-TT project provided valuable experience to a talent pool in business development, technology development, software engineering, and polymer informatics to undergraduate students, PhD researchers, and post-doctoral researchers.
  • Two undergraduate students funded by the project have gone on to pursuing doctoral degrees.

Company Progress:

  • With the momentum from the NSF PFI-TT grant, Matmerize is blossoming. The company is revenue-positive, cash-flow-positive and income-positive, and has a strong client base engaged in contract projects and software subscriptions.
  • In the last year, Matmerize secured two SBIR Phase I awards, one from NSF and another from ONR.
  • Five individuals from the talent pool created have been recruited as full-time employees by Matmerize in the past year.

Press Releases:

  • Matmerize secures DOD award to develop low-flammability polymer composite materials using advanced AI methods
  • Matmerize Inc. and CJ Biomaterials partner to utilize innovative AI technology to advance sustainable polymer solutions
  • Resonac Partners with Matmerize to Pioneer 6G Technology Advancement using Innovative AI Software

 


Last Modified: 06/15/2024
Modified by: Ramamurthy Ramprasad
por.por_txt_cntn:
Over the years, the Ramprasad Group at Georgia Tech has developed intellectual property (IP) and innovations in Polymer Informatics, which significantly accelerate the development, design, and optimization of polymers and formulations for various applications. The NSF PFI-TT grant has played a crucial role in advancing their polymer informatics software technology and facilitating its transition to the commercial space. The following are some key outcomes:


Technical Developments:



Collection and curation of data for dozens of polymer and composite properties.
Training machine learning models on this data to build property prediction models.
Creation of innovative algorithms for numerical polymer representation.
Development of new learning algorithms.
Creation of chemical and feature variant schemes for efficient chemical and parameter space searches.



Patent Filings:



Three patents have been filed, with one recently issued.



Market Validation:



A previous NSF I-Corps grant, along with ongoing customer discovery under the NSF PFI-TT grant, enabled the team to assess the market value of their technology. This included identifying target customer segments, validating and quantifying the value proposition, and determining product-market fit for their data-driven machine learning-based polymer property prediction and polymer design software.



Spinoff Formation:



A spinoff company, Matmerize, Inc., has been established. The developed polymer informatics technology and IP (including patents, software, and trade secrets) have been exclusively licensed to Matmerize by Georgia Tech.
Matmerize has developed a cloud-based materials design software called PolymRize, which can be accessed securely by polymer and formulations chemists via a web browser. This software uses proprietary data to build models that predict properties and aid in the rapid design of new polymers and formulations, aiming to set a new industry standard for cost-effective, accelerated polymer materials and formulation development.



Educational Impact:



The NSF PFI-TT project provided valuable experience to a talent pool in business development, technology development, software engineering, and polymer informatics to undergraduate students, PhD researchers, and post-doctoral researchers.
Two undergraduate students funded by the project have gone on to pursuing doctoral degrees.



Company Progress:



With the momentum from the NSF PFI-TT grant, Matmerize is blossoming. The company is revenue-positive, cash-flow-positive and income-positive, and has a strong client base engaged in contract projects and software subscriptions.
In the last year, Matmerize secured two SBIR Phase I awards, one from NSF and another from ONR.
Five individuals from the talent pool created have been recruited as full-time employees by Matmerize in the past year.
